title: BoQ profit slides and more pain tipped to come
text:
Bank of Queensland has seen earnings crumple and is telling the market to brace for worse in the coming year.

A tougher market for lending and gathering deposits, higher regulatory costs and other expenses rising were partly blamed.

New BoQ CEO George Frazis. Peter Braig

The 160-branch lender’s new chief executive George Frazis, who started last month after lengthy stints at major banks including Westpac, argued the business was fundamentally good.

But he added this financial year would be “difficult”. “We expect lower year-on-year cash earnings in [fiscal 2020] with revenue and impairment outcomes in line with [fiscal 2019], higher post-Hayne regulatory and compliance costs, and increased operating expenses related to our investment in technology,” he said.

It comes with Brisbane-based BoQ posting a drop in a swathe of profit measures. Statutory profits were down 11 per cent to $298 million, cash earnings down 14 per cent to $320 million and cost-to-income ratio - a measure of business efficiency - higher at 50.5 per cent.
description: A tougher market for lending and gathering deposits, higher regulatory costs and other expenses rising were partly blamed.
